subject: probability
title: Conditional Independence
contentHtml:
In probability theory, conditional independence is a crucial concept that helps us understand how events are related when given additional information.

Intuitively, two random variables X and Y are conditionally independent given Z if the knowledge of Z 'decouples' their relationships. In other words, knowing Z doesn't provide any additional information about the relationship between X and Y.
intuition: Think of it like a conversation. When you're talking to someone, your friend's presence doesn't affect the topic of discussion unless there's a specific connection between them.
realWorldApplications: In graphical models, conditional independence is used to simplify complex probability distributions and improve inference algorithms.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse conditional independence with unconditional independence. The latter only considers the variables themselves, not additional information.

subject: probability
title: Conditional Independence
contentHtml:
In probability theory, conditional independence is a crucial concept that helps us understand how variables are related when given some additional information.

Intuitively, two random variables X and Y are conditionally independent given Z if the probability distribution of X and Y depends only on Z, not on each other.
intuition: Think of it like a conversation: when you're given some context (Z), the topics discussed by X and Y become irrelevant to each other.
realWorldApplications: In graphical models, conditional independence is used to define the structure of Bayesian networks.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse conditional independence with unconditional independence!

subject: probability
title: Conditional Independence
contentHtml:
In probability theory, conditional independence is a crucial concept that helps us understand relationships between random variables.

Given two sets of variables X and Y, we say they are conditionally independent given Z if the probability distribution of X and Y depends only on Z. Mathematically, this can be expressed as:

\(P(X \perp Y | Z) = P(X | Z) P(Y | Z)\)

This concept is essential in graphical models, where it helps us simplify complex relationships between variables.

intuition: Think of conditional independence as saying that once we know the value of Z, X and Y become independent. This is useful in modeling complex systems where there are multiple variables interacting with each other.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, conditional independence helps us identify features that are not correlated with each other, which can improve model performance.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse conditional independence with unconditional independence. The latter only considers the joint distribution of X and Y, whereas the former takes into account a third variable Z.
